comment_text.mn60:1.1: This sutta subverts the imagery of gambling by reasoning towards logical certitude in a world of apparently random chances. Gambling was a major feature of Vedic culture, with the moving confession of Rig Veda 10.34 recounting the thrill and loss of the game. The gods were invoked to ensure success (Atharvaveda 7.109). Even kings bowed to the dice (Rig Veda 10.34.8), so that the Rājasūya consecration ceremony is secured with a (loaded) game of dice (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 5.4.4.6, 23). Numerous tales of kings losing their realms at dice, most notably Yudhiṣṭhira in the Mahābhārata, show that the power and danger of gambling was not merely symbolic.
comment_text.mn60:1.2: The same framing narrative recurs at MN 41, where the topic of rebirth is also at stake.
comment_text.mn60:4.1: The Brahmanical community was in a period of questioning and transition, with multiple different perspectives offered by both Brahmins and ascetics.
comment_text.mn60:4.3: While the contextual sense of the key term apaṇṇaka (“unfailing”) is clear, the etymology has proven a puzzle. I propose that it is a gambling term, and paṇṇa appears as a form of the number five. While a set of four dice was “perfect”, the fifth “losing” (kali) die was all-powerful, since just one extra die meant you lose everything (Rig Veda 10.34.2, Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 5.4.4.6). Apaṇṇaka is therefore literally a “set without a fifth” and metaphorically “without fail”.
comment_text.mn60:5.2: At DN 2:23.2 this is presented as the moral view of Ajita of the Hair Blanket, who justifies it with a materialist theory.
comment_text.mn60:6.3: The positive side is of course the Buddha’s view.
comment_text.mn60:9.2: Given that they no longer exist, how are they safe? Bodhi’s “will have made himself safe” is unlikely, as it is future perfect, a rare sense that requires the past participle. Anyway he hasn’t “made himself” anything, he just happen to live in a world without moral consequences. Horner notes the problem without offering a solution, there are no parallels, and commentaries are silent. I think the text is corrupt.
comment_text.mn60:9.4: The syntax of this sentence is tricky. Kāmaṁ is “willingly”, which together with hotu conveys the sense “let us grant …”. Māhu resolves to mā ahu, a simple negation rather than a prohibition. For kāmaṁ with mā and imperative, compare SN 11.4:7.1.
comment_text.mn60:9.5: “Nihilist” is natthikavāda, “one whose doctrine is that there is nothing”. While this view is discussed many times in the suttas, the word natthikavāda is elsewhere only applied to a specific pair of persons, Vassa and Bhañña of Ukkalā (MN 117:38.1, SN 22.62:13.2, AN 4.30:8.2).
comment_text.mn60:9.8: It is difficult to choose between “skillful” and “wholesome” as renderings for kusala. “Skillful” sticks closer to the root sense, while “wholesome” is more idiomatic. But the context here well illustrates that the root sense is still alive in the language, as the “skillful” option is that which wisely aligns cause and effect with one’s own well-being.
comment_text.mn60:12.5: “Perfect hand” (kaṭaggaha) is an expression from the classical Vedic game of chance. The details are obscure and would have changed over time, but it seems that a large quantity of vibhītaka (“bedda”) nuts were cast in a hollow, from which players took a handful. If the number of nuts was divisible by four, it was said to be a “perfect” (kaṭa; see Rig Veda 1.132.1, etc.) “hand” (gāha). | Apaṇṇaka and kaṭaggāha are also connected at SN 42.13:23.5; compare the “gem” thrown like a loaded die at AN 3.118:4.6 and AN 10.217:17.1. Good rebirth is further compared to a “perfect hand” at MN 129:49.1. And at Ja 1:2.4, a wise person would “take up” (gaṇhe) what is unfailing, namely a winning hand.
comment_text.mn60:13.2: At DN 2:17.2, this denial of the doctrine of kamma is attributed to Pūraṇa Kassapa. He may have subscribed to hard determinism, so that we have no choice in what we do. He may also have believed that we should keep moral rules as a social contract, but that this had no effect on the afterlife. | In such contexts, kar- means “punish, inflict” (MN 129:29.2).
comment_text.mn60:17.5: “One who denies the efficacy of action” is akiriyavāda.
comment_text.mn60:21.2: At DN 2:20.2 this view is attributed to the Bamboo-staffed Ascetic Gosāla, the founder of the Ājīvikas and teacher of fatalism. It is attributed to Pūraṇa Kassapa at SN 22.60:2.2.
comment_text.mn60:25.5: “One who denies causality” is ahetukavāda.
comment_text.mn60:29.2: The four “formless states” (āruppā) are attained with the “total” (sabbaso) surmounting of form. While the previous views characterize prominent ascetic movements, the final view relates to the formless meditations, the cardinal teaching of the contemplative movement of the Kosalan brahmins, represented by such figures as Āḷāra Kālāma and Uddaka Rāmaputta (MN 36:14.9) or the sixteen brahmins of the Pārāyanavagga (Snp 5.1 ff.). The Buddha elevates his teaching by directly addressing the highest and best of contemporary Brahmanical practices.
comment_text.mn60:32.2: This denies the basic tenet of dependent origination. Bhava means “being”, but in the pregnant philosophical sense of “continued existence”, which often takes the form of “future lives”. It can be broader than that, however, as with the Upaniṣadic doctrine of eternal unity of the contingent personal self with the absolute universal divinity. Since the Brahmins saw the cosmos as an expression of divinity, to them, existence must be inherently good and the cessation of existence abhorrent.
comment_text.mn60:38.2: Pali here is abbreviated, and I have expanded partially for clarity. For the full text, see MN 51:10.8.

root_text.mn60:37.2: Idha, gahapatayo, ekacco puggalo orabbhiko hoti sūkariko …pe… ye vā panaññepi keci kurūrakammantā.
root_text.mn60:37.3: Ayaṁ vuccati, gahapatayo, puggalo parantapo paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
root_text.mn60:38.1: Katamo ca, gahapatayo, puggalo attantapo ca attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto?
root_text.mn60:38.2: Idha, gahapatayo, ekacco puggalo rājā vā hoti khattiyo muddhāvasitto …pe…
root_text.mn60:38.3: tepi daṇḍatajjitā bhayatajjitā assumukhā rudamānā parikammāni karonti.
root_text.mn60:38.4: Ayaṁ vuccati, gahapatayo, puggalo attantapo ca attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
root_text.mn60:39.1: Katamo ca, gahapatayo, puggalo nevattantapo nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto;

root_text.mn60:40-54.1: Idha, gahapatayo, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṁ sammāsambuddho …

root_text.mn60:40-54.4: vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn60:40-54.5: Vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ …pe…
root_text.mn60:55.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn60:55.2: So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.
root_text.mn60:55.3: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṁ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn60:55.4: So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate …pe… yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
root_text.mn60:55.5: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṁ khayañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn60:55.8: Tassa evaṁ jānato evaṁ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati.
root_text.mn60:55.10: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.

root_text.mn60:57.1: Evaṁ vutte, sāleyyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ:
root_text.mn60:57.3: Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṁ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṁ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṁ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṁ dhāreyya ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṁ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
root_text.mn60:57.4: Ete mayaṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāma dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
root_text.mn60:57.5: Upāsake no bhavaṁ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṁ saraṇaṁ gate”ti.

translation_text.mn60:1.2: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a village of the Kosalan brahmins named Sālā.
translation_text.mn60:2.1: The brahmins and householders of Sālā heard:
translation_text.mn60:2.2: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—wandering in the land of the Kosalans has arrived at Sālā, together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
translation_text.mn60:2.4: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
translation_text.mn60:2.5: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
translation_text.mn60:2.6: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
translation_text.mn60:2.7: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
translation_text.mn60:3.1: Then the brahmins and householders of Sālā went up to the Buddha. Before sitting down to one side, some bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent. The Buddha said to them:
translation_text.mn60:4.1: “So, householders, is there any teacher you’re happy with, in whom you have acquired grounded faith?”
translation_text.mn60:4.3: “Since you haven’t found a teacher you’re happy with, you should undertake and implement this unfailing teaching.
translation_text.mn60:4.4: For when the unfailing teaching is undertaken, it will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.
translation_text.mn60:4.5: And what is the unfailing teaching?
translation_text.mn60:5.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
translation_text.mn60:5.2: ‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There’s no such thing as mother and father, or beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’
translation_text.mn60:6.1: And there are some ascetics and brahmins whose doctrine directly contradicts this.
translation_text.mn60:6.3: ‘There is meaning in giving, sacrifice, and offerings. There are fruits and results of good and bad deeds. There is an afterlife. There are such things as mother and father, and beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there are ascetics and brahmins who are rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describe the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’
translation_text.mn60:6.5: Don’t these doctrines directly contradict each other?”
translation_text.mn60:7.1: “Since this is so, consider those ascetics and brahmins whose view is that
translation_text.mn60:7.2: there’s no meaning in giving, etc.
translation_text.mn60:7.3: You can expect that they will shun good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and undertake and implement bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.
translation_text.mn60:7.5: Because those ascetics and brahmins don’t see that unskillful qualities are full of drawbacks, sordidness, and corruption, or that skillful qualities have the benefit and cleansing power of renunciation.
translation_text.mn60:8.1: Moreover, since there actually is another world, their view that there is no other world is wrong view.
translation_text.mn60:8.2: Since there actually is another world, their thought that there is no other world is wrong thought.
translation_text.mn60:8.3: Since there actually is another world, their speech that there is no other world is wrong speech.
translation_text.mn60:8.4: Since there actually is another world, in saying that there is no other world they contradict those perfected ones who know the other world.
translation_text.mn60:8.5: Since there actually is another world, in persuading another that there is no other world they are persuading them to accept an untrue teaching.
translation_text.mn60:8.6: And on account of that they glorify themselves and put others down.
translation_text.mn60:8.7: So they give up their former ethical conduct and are established in unethical conduct.
translation_text.mn60:8.8: And that is how these many bad, unskillful qualities come to be with wrong view as condition—wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, contradicting the noble ones, persuading others to accept untrue teachings, and glorifying oneself and putting others down.
translation_text.mn60:9.1: A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way:
translation_text.mn60:9.2: ‘If there is no other world, when this individual person’s body breaks up they will keep themselves safe.
translation_text.mn60:9.3: And if there is another world, when their body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
translation_text.mn60:9.4: But let us grant that those who say that there is no other world are correct.
translation_text.mn60:9.5: Regardless, that individual is still criticized by sensible people in this very life as being an immoral individual of wrong view, a nihilist.’
translation_text.mn60:9.6: But if there really is another world, they hold a losing hand on both counts.
translation_text.mn60:9.7: For they are criticized by sensible people in this very life, and when their body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
translation_text.mn60:9.8: They have wrongly undertaken this unfailing teaching in such a way that it encompasses the positive outcomes of one side only, leaving out the skillful premise.

translation_text.mn60:11.2: Since there actually is another world, their thought that there is another world is right thought.
translation_text.mn60:11.3: Since there actually is another world, their speech that there is another world is right speech.
translation_text.mn60:11.4: Since there actually is another world, in saying that there is another world they don’t contradict those perfected ones who know the other world.
translation_text.mn60:11.5: Since there actually is another world, in persuading another that there is another world they are persuading them to accept a true teaching.
translation_text.mn60:11.6: And on account of that they don’t glorify themselves or put others down.
translation_text.mn60:11.7: So they give up their former unethical conduct and are established in ethical conduct.
translation_text.mn60:11.8: And that is how these many skillful qualities come to be with right view as condition—right view, right thought, right speech, not contradicting the noble ones, persuading others to accept true teachings, and not glorifying oneself or putting others down.

translation_text.mn60:12.2: ‘If there is another world, when this individual’s body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
translation_text.mn60:12.3: But let us grant that those who say that there is no other world are correct.
translation_text.mn60:12.4: Regardless, that individual is still praised by sensible people in this very life as being a moral individual of right view, who affirms a positive teaching.’
translation_text.mn60:12.5: So if there really is another world, they hold a perfect hand on both counts.
translation_text.mn60:12.6: For they are praised by sensible people in this very life, and when their body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
translation_text.mn60:12.7: They have rightly undertaken this unfailing teaching in such a way that it encompasses the positive outcomes of both sides, leaving out the unskillful premise.
translation_text.mn60:13.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
translation_text.mn60:13.2: ‘The one who acts does nothing wrong when they punish, mutilate, torture, aggrieve, oppress, intimidate, or when they encourage others to do the same. They do nothing wrong when they kill, steal, break into houses, plunder wealth, steal from isolated buildings, commit highway robbery, commit adultery, and lie.
translation_text.mn60:13.3: If you were to reduce all the living creatures of this earth to one heap and mass of flesh with a razor-edged chakram, no evil comes of that, and no outcome of evil.
translation_text.mn60:13.4: If you were to go along the south bank of the Ganges killing, mutilating, and torturing, and encouraging others to do the same, no evil comes of that, and no outcome of evil.
translation_text.mn60:13.5: If you were to go along the north bank of the Ganges giving and sacrificing and encouraging others to do the same, no merit comes of that, and no outcome of merit.
translation_text.mn60:13.6: In giving, self-control, restraint, and truthfulness there is no merit or outcome of merit.’
translation_text.mn60:14.1: And there are some ascetics and brahmins whose doctrine directly contradicts this. They say:
translation_text.mn60:14.2: ‘The one who acts does a bad deed when they punish, mutilate, torture, aggrieve, oppress, intimidate, or when they encourage others to do the same. They do a bad deed when they kill, steal, break into houses, plunder wealth, steal from isolated buildings, commit highway robbery, commit adultery, and lie.
translation_text.mn60:14.3: If you were to reduce all the living creatures of this earth to one heap and mass of flesh with a razor-edged chakram, evil comes of that, and an outcome of evil.
translation_text.mn60:14.4: If you were to go along the south bank of the Ganges killing, mutilating, and torturing, and encouraging others to do the same, evil comes of that, and an outcome of evil.
translation_text.mn60:14.5: If you were to go along the north bank of the Ganges giving and sacrificing and encouraging others to do the same, merit comes of that, and an outcome of merit.
translation_text.mn60:14.6: In giving, self-control, restraint, and truthfulness there is merit and outcome of merit.’
translation_text.mn60:14.8: Don’t these doctrines directly contradict each other?”

translation_text.mn60:21.3: Sentient beings are corrupted without cause or reason.

translation_text.mn60:21.5: Sentient beings are purified without cause or reason.
translation_text.mn60:21.6: There is no power, no energy, no human strength or vigor.
translation_text.mn60:21.7: All sentient beings, all living creatures, all beings, all souls lack control, power, and energy. Molded by destiny, circumstance, and nature, they experience pleasure and pain in the six classes of rebirth.’

translation_text.mn60:28.1: A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way: ‘If there is causality, when this individual’s body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
translation_text.mn60:28.2: But let us grant that those who say that there is no causality are correct.
translation_text.mn60:28.3: Regardless, that individual is still praised by sensible people in this very life as being a moral individual of right view, who affirms causality.’
translation_text.mn60:28.4: So if there really is causality, they hold a perfect hand on both counts.
translation_text.mn60:28.5: For they are praised by sensible people in this very life, and when their body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
translation_text.mn60:28.6: They have rightly undertaken this unfailing teaching in such a way that it encompasses the positive outcomes of both sides, leaving out the unskillful premise.
translation_text.mn60:29.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
translation_text.mn60:29.2: ‘There are no totally formless states of meditation.’
translation_text.mn60:30.1: And there are some ascetics and brahmins whose doctrine directly contradicts this.
translation_text.mn60:30.3: ‘There are totally formless states of meditation.’
translation_text.mn60:30.5: Don’t these doctrines directly contradict each other?”
translation_text.mn60:31.1: “A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way:
translation_text.mn60:31.3: there are no totally formless meditations, but I have not seen that.
translation_text.mn60:31.4: Some ascetics and brahmins say that
translation_text.mn60:31.5: there are totally formless meditations, but I have not known that.
translation_text.mn60:31.6: Without knowing or seeing, it would not be appropriate for me to take one side and declare,
translation_text.mn60:31.7: ‘This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’
translation_text.mn60:31.8: If those ascetics and brahmins who say that
translation_text.mn60:31.9: there are no totally formless meditations are correct, it is possible
translation_text.mn60:31.10: that I will be unfailingly reborn among the gods who are formed and made of mind.
translation_text.mn60:31.11: If those ascetics and brahmins who say that
translation_text.mn60:31.12: there are totally formless meditations are correct, it is possible
translation_text.mn60:31.13: that I will be unfailingly reborn among the gods who are formless and made of perception.
translation_text.mn60:31.14: Now, owing to form, bad things are seen: taking up the rod and the sword, quarrels, arguments, and disputes, accusations, divisive speech, and lies.
translation_text.mn60:31.15: But those things don’t exist where it is totally formless.’
translation_text.mn60:31.16: Reflecting like this, they simply practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding forms.
translation_text.mn60:32.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
translation_text.mn60:32.2: ‘There is no such thing as the total cessation of continued existence.’
translation_text.mn60:33.1: And there are some ascetics and brahmins whose doctrine directly contradicts this.
translation_text.mn60:33.3: ‘There is such a thing as the total cessation of continued existence.’
translation_text.mn60:33.5: Don’t these doctrines directly contradict each other?”
translation_text.mn60:34.1: “A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way:
translation_text.mn60:34.3: there is no such thing as the total cessation of continued existence, but I have not seen that.
translation_text.mn60:34.4: Some ascetics and brahmins say that
translation_text.mn60:34.5: there is such a thing as the total cessation of continued existence, but I have not known that.
translation_text.mn60:34.6: Without knowing or seeing, it would not be appropriate for me to take one side and declare,
translation_text.mn60:34.7: ‘This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’
translation_text.mn60:34.8: If those ascetics and brahmins who say that
translation_text.mn60:34.9: there is no such thing as the total cessation of continued existence are correct, it is possible
translation_text.mn60:34.10: that I will be unfailingly reborn among the gods who are formless and made of perception.
translation_text.mn60:34.11: If those ascetics and brahmins who say that
translation_text.mn60:34.12: there is such a thing as the total cessation of continued existence are correct, it is possible
translation_text.mn60:34.13: that I will be fully extinguished in this very life.
translation_text.mn60:34.14: The view of those ascetics and brahmins who say that
translation_text.mn60:34.15: there is no such thing as the total cessation of continued existence is close to greed, yoking, relishing, attachment, and grasping.
translation_text.mn60:34.16: The view of those ascetics and brahmins who say that
translation_text.mn60:34.17: there is such a thing as the total cessation of continued existence is close to non-greed, non-yoking, non-relishing, non-attachment, and non-grasping.’
translation_text.mn60:34.18: Reflecting like this, they simply practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding future lives.
translation_text.mn60:35.1: Householders, these four individuals are found in the world.
translation_text.mn60:35.3: One individual mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.
translation_text.mn60:35.4: One individual mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others.
translation_text.mn60:35.5: One individual mortifies themselves and others, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.
translation_text.mn60:35.6: One individual doesn’t mortify either themselves or others, committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others.
translation_text.mn60:35.7: They live without wishes in this very life, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine.
translation_text.mn60:36.1: And what individual mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves?
translation_text.mn60:36.2: It’s when a person goes naked, ignoring conventions. …
translation_text.mn60:36.3: And so they live committed to practicing these various ways of mortifying and tormenting the body.
translation_text.mn60:36.4: This is called an individual who mortifies themselves, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.
translation_text.mn60:37.1: And what individual mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others?
translation_text.mn60:37.2: It’s when an individual is a butcher of sheep, pigs, poultry, or deer, a hunter or fisher, a bandit, an executioner, a butcher of cattle, a jailer, or has some other cruel livelihood.
translation_text.mn60:37.3: This is called an individual who mortifies others, being committed to the practice of mortifying others.
translation_text.mn60:38.1: And what individual mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others?
translation_text.mn60:38.2: It’s when an individual is an anointed aristocratic king or a well-to-do brahmin. He has a new ceremonial hall built to the east of the citadel. He shaves off his hair and beard, dresses in a rough antelope hide, and smears his body with ghee and oil. …
translation_text.mn60:38.3: His bondservants, servants, and workers do their jobs under threat of punishment and danger, weeping, with tearful faces.
translation_text.mn60:38.4: This is called an individual who mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.
translation_text.mn60:39.1: And what individual doesn’t mortify either themselves or others, committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others,
translation_text.mn60:39.2: living without wishes in this very life, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine?
translation_text.mn60:40-54.1: It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha …
translation_text.mn60:40-54.2: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in some good family. …
translation_text.mn60:40-54.3: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.
translation_text.mn60:40-54.4: Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption …
translation_text.mn60:55.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives. …
translation_text.mn60:55.2: They recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
translation_text.mn60:55.3: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
translation_text.mn60:55.4: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. … They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.
translation_text.mn60:55.5: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
translation_text.mn60:55.6: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
translation_text.mn60:55.7: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
translation_text.mn60:55.8: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
translation_text.mn60:55.9: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
translation_text.mn60:55.10: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’
translation_text.mn60:56.1: This is called an individual who neither mortifies themselves or others, being committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others.
translation_text.mn60:56.2: They live without wishes in this very life, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine.”
translation_text.mn60:57.1: When he had spoken, the brahmins and householders of Sālā said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn60:57.3: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.
translation_text.mn60:57.4: We go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn60:57.5: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember us as lay followers who have gone for refuge for life.”
